# Independence Day (United States)

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to navigation Jump to search

"Fourth of July" and "4th of July" redirect here. For the date, see [July
4](/wiki/July_4 "July 4"). For other uses, see [Independence Day
(disambiguation)](/wiki/Independence_Day_\(disambiguation\) "Independence Day
\(disambiguation\)"). For other related material, see [Fourth of July
(disambiguation)](/wiki/Fourth_of_July_\(disambiguation\) "Fourth of July
\(disambiguation\)").

Independence Day

**Independence Day** ([colloquial](/wiki/Colloquial "Colloquial"): **the
Fourth of July** ; **July Fourth** ; **the Fourth**) is a [federal
holiday](/wiki/Federal_holidays_in_the_United_States "Federal holidays in the
United States") in the United States commemorating the adoption of the
[Declaration of Independence](/wiki/United_States_Declaration_of_Independence
"United States Declaration of Independence") on July 4, 1776. The [Continental
Congress](/wiki/Second_Continental_Congress "Second Continental Congress")
declared that the [thirteen American colonies](/wiki/Thirteen_colonies
"Thirteen colonies") regarded themselves as free and independent states, the
[United States of America](/wiki/United_States "United States"), and were no
longer connected to the British Crown.[1] The Congress actually voted to
declare independence two days earlier, on July 2.[1]

Independence Day is commonly associated with [fireworks](/wiki/Fireworks
"Fireworks"), [parades](/wiki/Parade "Parade"), [barbecues](/wiki/Barbecue
"Barbecue"), [carnivals](/wiki/Traveling_carnival "Traveling carnival"),
[fairs](/wiki/Funfair "Funfair"), [picnics](/wiki/Picnic "Picnic"),
[concerts](/wiki/Concert "Concert"), [baseball games](/wiki/Baseball
"Baseball"), [family reunions](/wiki/Family_reunion "Family reunion"), and
[political speeches](/wiki/Political_speech "Political speech") and
ceremonies, in addition to various other public and private events celebrating
the history, government, and traditions of the United States. Independence Day
is the [National Day](/wiki/National_Day "National Day") of the United
States.[2][3][4]

## Background

During the [American Revolution](/wiki/American_Revolution "American
Revolution"), the legal separation of the [Thirteen
Colonies](/wiki/Thirteen_Colonies "Thirteen Colonies") from Great Britain in
1776 actually occurred on July 2, when the [Second Continental
Congress](/wiki/Second_Continental_Congress "Second Continental Congress")
voted to approve a [resolution of independence](/wiki/Lee_Resolution "Lee
Resolution") that had been proposed in June by [Richard Henry
Lee](/wiki/Richard_Henry_Lee "Richard Henry Lee") of [Virginia](/wiki/Virginia
"Virginia") declaring the United States independent from Great Britain's
rule.[5][6] After voting for independence, Congress turned its attention to
the [Declaration of
Independence](/wiki/United_States_Declaration_of_Independence "United States
Declaration of Independence"), a statement explaining this decision, which had
been prepared by a [Committee of Five](/wiki/Committee_of_Five "Committee of
Five"), with [Thomas Jefferson](/wiki/Thomas_Jefferson "Thomas Jefferson") as
its principal author. Congress debated and revised the wording of the
Declaration, finally approving it two days later on July 4. A day earlier,
[John Adams](/wiki/John_Adams "John Adams") had written to his wife
[Abigail](/wiki/Abigail_Adams "Abigail Adams"):

> The second day of July, 1776, will be the most memorable epoch in the
> history of America. I am apt to believe that it will be celebrated by
> succeeding generations as the great anniversary festival. It ought to be
> commemorated as the day of deliverance, by solemn acts of devotion to God
> Almighty. It ought to be solemnized with pomp and parade, with shows, games,
> sports, guns, bells, bonfires, and illuminations, from one end of this
> continent to the other, from this time forward forever more.[7]

Adams's prediction was off by two days. From the outset, Americans celebrated
independence on July 4, the date shown on the much-publicized Declaration of
Independence, rather than on July 2, the date the resolution of independence
was approved in a closed session of Congress.[8]

Historians have long disputed whether members of Congress signed the
Declaration of Independence on July 4, even though Thomas Jefferson, John
Adams, and [Benjamin Franklin](/wiki/Benjamin_Franklin "Benjamin Franklin")
all later wrote that they had signed it on that day. Most historians have
concluded that the Declaration was signed nearly a month after its adoption,
on August 2, 1776, and not on July 4 as is commonly
believed.[9][10][11][12][13]

Coincidentally, both John Adams and Thomas Jefferson, the only signers of the
Declaration of Independence later to serve as [Presidents of the United
States](/wiki/President_of_the_United_States "President of the United
States"), died on the same day: July 4, 1826, which was the 50th anniversary
of the Declaration.[14] Although not a signer of the Declaration of
Independence, [James Monroe](/wiki/James_Monroe "James Monroe"), another
[Founding Father](/wiki/Founding_Fathers_of_the_United_States "Founding
Fathers of the United States") who was elected as President, also died on July
4, 1831. He was the third President who died on the anniversary of
independence.[15] [Calvin Coolidge](/wiki/Calvin_Coolidge "Calvin Coolidge"),
the 30th President, was born on July 4, 1872; so far he is the only U.S.
President to have been born on Independence Day.[16]

## Observance

  * In 1777, thirteen [gunshots](/wiki/Gunshot "Gunshot") were fired in salute, once at morning and once again as evening fell, on July 4 in [Bristol, Rhode Island](/wiki/Bristol,_Rhode_Island "Bristol, Rhode Island"). An article in July 18, 1777 issue of _[The Virginia Gazette](/wiki/The_Virginia_Gazette "The Virginia Gazette")_ noted a celebration in Philadelphia in a manner a modern American would find familiar: an official dinner for the Continental Congress, toasts, [13-gun salutes](/wiki/Saluting_guns "Saluting guns"), speeches, prayers, music, parades, troop reviews, and fireworks. Ships in port were decked with red, white, and blue bunting.[17]
  * In 1778, from his headquarters at [Ross Hall](/wiki/Ross_Hall "Ross Hall"), near [New Brunswick, New Jersey](/wiki/New_Brunswick,_New_Jersey "New Brunswick, New Jersey"), General [George Washington](/wiki/George_Washington "George Washington") marked July 4 with a double ration of [rum](/wiki/Rum "Rum") for his soldiers and an artillery salute (_[feu de joie](/wiki/Feu_de_joie "Feu de joie")_). Across the Atlantic Ocean, [ambassadors](/wiki/Ambassador_\(diplomacy\) "Ambassador \(diplomacy\)") John Adams and [Benjamin Franklin](/wiki/Benjamin_Franklin "Benjamin Franklin") held a dinner for their fellow Americans in [Paris](/wiki/Paris "Paris"), France.[18]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c1/American_1902_Fourth_of_July_fireworks.jpg/400px-
American_1902_Fourth_of_July_fireworks.jpg)](/wiki/File:American_1902_Fourth_of_July_fireworks.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:American_1902_Fourth_of_July_fireworks.jpg "Enlarge")

American children of many ethnic backgrounds celebrate noisily in 1902 _Puck_
cartoon

  * In 1779, July 4 fell on a Sunday. The holiday was celebrated on Monday, July 5.[18]
  * In 1781, the [Massachusetts General Court](/wiki/Massachusetts_General_Court "Massachusetts General Court") became the first [state legislature](/wiki/State_legislature_\(United_States\) "State legislature \(United States\)") to recognize July 4 as a state celebration.[18]
  * In 1783, [Salem, North Carolina](/wiki/Old_Salem "Old Salem") held a celebration with a challenging music program assembled by [Johann Friedrich Peter](/wiki/Johann_Friedrich_Peter "Johann Friedrich Peter") entitled _The Psalm of Joy_. The town claims to be the first public July 4 event, as it was carefully documented by the [Moravian Church](/wiki/Moravian_Church "Moravian Church"), and there are no government records of any earlier celebrations.[19]
  * In 1870, the [U.S. Congress](/wiki/United_States_Congress "United States Congress") made Independence Day an unpaid holiday for federal employees.[20]
  * In 1938, Congress changed Independence Day to a paid federal holiday.[21]

## Customs

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a2/InvitationIndependenceDayGreenwichCT06201825.jpg/290px-
InvitationIndependenceDayGreenwichCT06201825.jpg)](/wiki/File:InvitationIndependenceDayGreenwichCT06201825.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:InvitationIndependenceDayGreenwichCT06201825.jpg "Enlarge")

An 1825 invitation to an Independence Day celebration

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6c/Firework_in_sky.jpg/220px-
Firework_in_sky.jpg)](/wiki/File:Firework_in_sky.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Firework_in_sky.jpg "Enlarge")

Fireworks on Independence Day in [Goleta, California](/wiki/Goleta,_California
"Goleta, California")

Independence Day is a [national holiday](/wiki/National_Day "National Day")
marked by patriotic displays. Similar to other summer-themed events,
Independence Day celebrations often take place outdoors. According to [5
U.S.C.](/wiki/Title_5_of_the_United_States_Code "Title 5 of the United States
Code") [§ 6103](https://www.law.cornell.edu/uscode/text/5/6103), Independence
Day is a federal holiday, so all non-essential federal institutions (such as
the [postal service](/wiki/United_States_Postal_Service "United States Postal
Service") and [federal courts](/wiki/United_States_federal_courts "United
States federal courts")) are closed on that day. Many politicians make it a
point on this day to appear at a public event to praise the nation's heritage,
laws, history, society, and people.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

Families often celebrate Independence Day by hosting or attending a picnic or
barbecue; many take advantage of the day off and, in some years, a long
weekend to gather with relatives or friends. Decorations (_e.g._ , streamers,
balloons, and clothing) are generally colored red, white, and blue, the colors
of the [American flag](/wiki/Flag_of_the_United_States "Flag of the United
States"). Parades are often held in the morning, before family get-togethers,
while fireworks displays occur in the evening after dark at such places as
parks, fairgrounds, or town squares.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

The night before the Fourth was once the focal point of celebrations, marked
by raucous gatherings often incorporating [bonfires](/wiki/Bonfires
"Bonfires") as their centerpiece. In [New England](/wiki/New_England "New
England"), towns competed to build towering pyramids, assembled from barrels
and casks. They were lit at nightfall to usher in the celebration. The highest
were in [Salem, Massachusetts](/wiki/Salem,_Massachusetts "Salem,
Massachusetts"), with pyramids composed of as many as forty tiers of barrels.
These made the tallest bonfires ever recorded. The custom flourished in the
19th and 20th centuries and is still practiced in some [New
England](/wiki/New_England "New England") towns.[22]

Independence Day [fireworks](/wiki/Fireworks "Fireworks") are often
accompanied by patriotic songs such as the [national
anthem](/wiki/National_anthem "National anthem"), "[The Star-Spangled
Banner](/wiki/The_Star-Spangled_Banner "The Star-Spangled Banner")"; "[God
Bless America](/wiki/God_Bless_America "God Bless America")"; "[America the
Beautiful](/wiki/America_the_Beautiful "America the Beautiful")"; "[My
Country, 'Tis of Thee](/wiki/My_Country,_%27Tis_of_Thee "My Country, 'Tis of
Thee")"; "[This Land Is Your Land](/wiki/This_Land_Is_Your_Land "This Land Is
Your Land")"; "[Stars and Stripes Forever](/wiki/Stars_and_Stripes_Forever
"Stars and Stripes Forever")"; and, regionally, "[Yankee
Doodle](/wiki/Yankee_Doodle "Yankee Doodle")" in northeastern states and
"[Dixie](/wiki/Dixie_\(song\) "Dixie \(song\)")" in southern states. Some of
the lyrics recall images of the [Revolutionary
War](/wiki/American_Revolutionary_War "American Revolutionary War") or the
[War of 1812](/wiki/War_of_1812 "War of 1812").[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/37/4th_of_July_Independence_Day_Parade_2014_DC_%2814466486678%29.jpg/220px-4th_of_July_Independence_Day_Parade_2014_DC_%2814466486678%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:4th_of_July_Independence_Day_Parade_2014_DC_\(14466486678\).jpg)

[](/wiki/File:4th_of_July_Independence_Day_Parade_2014_DC_\(14466486678\).jpg
"Enlarge")

Independence Day Parade in Washington, D.C.

Firework shows are held in many states, and many fireworks are sold for
personal use or as an alternative to a public show. Safety concerns have led
some states to ban fireworks or limit the sizes and types allowed. In
addition, local and regional weather conditions may dictate whether the sale
or use of fireworks in an area will be allowed. Some local or regional
firework sales are limited or prohibited because of dry weather or other
specific concerns. On these occasions the public may be prohibited from
purchasing or discharging fireworks, but professional displays (such as those
at sports events) may still take place, if certain safety precautions have
been taken.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

A salute of one gun for each state in the United States, called a "salute to
the union," is fired on Independence Day at noon by any capable military
base.[23]

New York City has the largest fireworks display in the country, with more than
22 tons of pyrotechnics exploded in 2009.[24] It generally holds displays in
the East River. Other major displays are in Seattle on [Lake
Union](/wiki/Lake_Union "Lake Union"); in San Diego over [Mission
Bay](/wiki/Mission_Bay,_San_Diego,_California "Mission Bay, San Diego,
California"); in Boston on the [Charles River](/wiki/Charles_River "Charles
River"); in Philadelphia over the [Philadelphia Museum of
Art](/wiki/Philadelphia_Museum_of_Art "Philadelphia Museum of Art"); in San
Francisco over the [San Francisco Bay](/wiki/San_Francisco_Bay "San Francisco
Bay"); and on the [National Mall](/wiki/National_Mall "National Mall") in
Washington, D.C.[25]

During the annual [Windsor–Detroit International Freedom
Festival](/wiki/Windsor%E2%80%93Detroit_International_Freedom_Festival
"Windsor–Detroit International Freedom Festival"), [Detroit,
Michigan](/wiki/Detroit "Detroit") hosts one of the largest fireworks displays
in North America, over the [Detroit River](/wiki/Detroit_River "Detroit
River"), to celebrate Independence Day in conjunction with [Windsor,
Ontario](/wiki/Windsor,_Ontario "Windsor, Ontario")'s celebration of [Canada
Day](/wiki/Canada_Day "Canada Day").[26]

The first week of July is typically one of the busiest United States travel
periods of the year, as many people use what is often a three-day holiday
weekend for extended vacation trips.[27]

## Notable celebrations

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fe/Spirit_of_%2776.jpg/220px-
Spirit_of_%2776.jpg)](/wiki/File:Spirit_of_%2776.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Spirit_of_%2776.jpg "Enlarge")

Originally entitled _[Yankee Doodle](/wiki/Yankee_Doodle "Yankee Doodle")_ ,
this is one of several versions of a scene painted by [A. M.
Willard](/wiki/Archibald_MacNeal_Willard "Archibald MacNeal Willard") that
came to be known as _The Spirit of '76_. Often imitated or parodied, it is a
familiar symbol of American patriotism

  * Held since 1785, the [Bristol Fourth of July Parade](/wiki/Bristol_Fourth_of_July_Parade "Bristol Fourth of July Parade") in [Bristol, Rhode Island](/wiki/Bristol,_Rhode_Island "Bristol, Rhode Island"), is the oldest continuous Independence Day celebration in the United States.[28]
  * Since 1868, [Seward, Nebraska](/wiki/Seward,_Nebraska "Seward, Nebraska"), has held a celebration on the same town square. In 1979 Seward was designated "America's Official Fourth of July City-Small Town USA" by resolution of Congress. Seward has also been proclaimed "Nebraska's Official Fourth of July City" by Governor James Exon in proclamation. Seward is a town of 6,000 but swells to 40,000+ during the July 4 celebrations.[29]
  * Since 1912, the Rebild Society, a Danish-American friendship organization, has held a July 4 weekend festival that serves as a homecoming for Danish-Americans in the [Rebild Hills](/wiki/Rebild_Hills "Rebild Hills") of [Denmark](/wiki/Denmark "Denmark").[30]
  * Since 1959, the [International Freedom Festival](/wiki/Windsor-Detroit_International_Freedom_Festival "Windsor-Detroit International Freedom Festival") is jointly held in Detroit, Michigan and [Windsor, Ontario](/wiki/Windsor,_Ontario "Windsor, Ontario") during the last week of June each year as a mutual celebration of Independence Day and [Canada Day](/wiki/Canada_Day "Canada Day") (July 1). It culminates in a large fireworks display over the [Detroit River](/wiki/Detroit_River "Detroit River").
  * The famous [Macy's](/wiki/Macy%27s "Macy's") fireworks display usually held over the [East River](/wiki/East_River "East River") in New York City has been televised nationwide on [NBC](/wiki/NBC "NBC") since 1976. In 2009, the fireworks display was returned to the [Hudson River](/wiki/Hudson_River "Hudson River") for the first time since 2000 to commemorate the 400th anniversary of [Henry Hudson](/wiki/Henry_Hudson "Henry Hudson")'s exploration of that river.[31]
  * The [Boston Pops Orchestra](/wiki/Boston_Pops_Orchestra "Boston Pops Orchestra") has hosted a music and fireworks show over the [Charles River Esplanade](/wiki/Charles_River_Esplanade "Charles River Esplanade") called the "Boston Pops Fireworks Spectacular" annually since 1973.[32] The event was broadcast nationally from 1991 until 2002 on [A&E](/wiki/A%26E_\(TV_channel\) "A&E \(TV channel\)"), and since 2002 by [CBS](/wiki/CBS "CBS") and its Boston station [WBZ-TV](/wiki/WBZ-TV "WBZ-TV"). [WBZ/1030](/wiki/WBZ_\(AM\) "WBZ \(AM\)") and WBZ-TV broadcast the entire event locally, and from 2002 through 2012, CBS broadcast the final hour of the concert nationally in primetime. The national broadcast was put on hiatus beginning in 2013, which Pops executive producer [David G. Mugar](/wiki/David_G._Mugar "David G. Mugar") believed was the result of decreasing viewership [caused by](/wiki/Counterprogramming "Counterprogramming") NBC's encore presentation of the Macy's fireworks.[33][34] The national broadcast was revived for 2016, and expanded to two hours.[35] In 2017, [Bloomberg Television](/wiki/Bloomberg_Television "Bloomberg Television") took over coverage duty, with [WHDH](/wiki/WHDH_\(TV\) "WHDH \(TV\)") carrying local coverage beginning in 2018.[36]
  * On the [Capitol](/wiki/United_States_Capitol "United States Capitol") lawn in Washington, D.C., _[A Capitol Fourth](/wiki/A_Capitol_Fourth "A Capitol Fourth")_ , a free concert broadcast live by [PBS](/wiki/Public_Broadcasting_Service "Public Broadcasting Service"), [NPR](/wiki/NPR "NPR") and the [American Forces Network](/wiki/American_Forces_Network "American Forces Network"), precedes the fireworks and attracts over half a million people annually.[37]

## Other countries

[The Philippines](/wiki/The_Philippines "The Philippines") celebrates July 4
as its [Republic Day](/wiki/Republic_Day_\(Philippines\) "Republic Day
\(Philippines\)") to commemorate that day in 1946 when it ceased to be a [U.S.
territory](/wiki/U.S._territory "U.S. territory") and the United States
officially recognized [Philippine
Independence](/wiki/History_of_the_Philippines_\(1946%E2%80%9365\) "History of
the Philippines \(1946–65\)").[38] July 4 was intentionally chosen by the
United States because it corresponds to its Independence Day, and this day was
observed in the Philippines as [Independence
Day](/wiki/Independence_Day_\(Philippines\) "Independence Day
\(Philippines\)") until 1962. In 1964, the name of the July 4 holiday was
changed to Republic Day. [Rebild National Park](/wiki/Rebild_National_Park
"Rebild National Park") in Denmark is said to hold the largest July 4
celebrations outside of the United States.[39]
